title: Trevor Bauer Became Baseball’s Highest-Paid Player. The Dodgers Got a Tax Break.
sub_head: Bauer can earn $85 million in two years under his unusual short-term free-agent contract with the Dodgers–who can soften the penalties for their high payroll.
body:
Trevor Bauer, by almost any objective measure, is not the best player in baseball. For the next two seasons, however, Bauer will likely be the highest-paid player in baseball.
The reason why says a lot about Bauer’s unorthodox priorities and the lengths teams will go to find new ways to game the complex universe of player salaries.
Bauer, a 30-year-old pitcher who won National League Cy Young honors in 2020, finalized one of the most unusual and fascinating contracts in American professional sports this week: a three-year pact with the Los Angeles Dodgers worth $102 million.
Except it’s more complicated than that. The agreement is essentially three separate one-year deals, giving Bauer the option to return to the free-agent market after each season. It calls for him averaging $42.5 million in compensation in 2021 and 2022, far surpassing any of his peers.
It’s after that when things get really interesting. Bauer’s contract is structured so that it’s unlikely he exercises his option for the third season, making it a three-year deal that really isn’t for three years.
